Graphical abstract The recent progress about the strategies and mechanisms proposed for improving Na-storage performance of the pitch-based carbon anodes. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have attracted significant attentions as promising alternatives to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage applications. Here carbon materials are considered as the most competitive anodes for SIBs based on their low-cost, abundant availability and excellent structural stability. Pitch, with high carbon content and low cost, is an ideal raw precursor to prepare carbon materials for large-scale applications. Nevertheless, the microstructures of pitch-based carbon are highly ordered with smaller interlayer distances, which are unfavorable for Na ion storage. Many efforts have been made to improve the sodium storage performance of pitch-based carbon materials. This review summarizes the recent progress about the application of pitch-based carbons for SIBs anodes in the context of carbon's morphology and structure regulation strategies, including morphology adjustment, heteroatoms doping, fabricating heterostructures, and the increase of the degree of disorder. Besides, the advantages, present challenges, and possible solutions to current issues in pitch-based carbon anode are discussed, with the highlight of future research directions. This review will provide a deep insight into the development of low-cost and high-performance pitch-based carbon anode for SIBs. Keywords Pitch Carbon anode Sodium-ion batteries Structure regulation Electrochemical performance 1 Introduction The development of clean and sustainable energy has drawn worldwide attentions, based on the growing energy and environmental issues in the world. The regional and intermittent dependence of renewable energy resources (solar, wind, wave) have urged the fast development of electrical energy storage (EES) technologies [1–3]. Among the various available EES technologies, rechargeable batteries with high conversion efficiency and flexible power are considered as the most successful technology [4]. In particular, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with high energy and power density, high voltage, long lifespan, and pollution-free operation options have quickly dominated the market, with extensive usage in portable electronic devices, hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) and electric vehicles (EVs) [5]. However, with the significant rise in the energy storage demand, the lithium consumption has increased, and the uneven geographical distribution and the limited lithium resources are indicative of its shortfalls for future demand, especially for the grid-scale energy storage applications [6]. At the same time, the price of lithium is anticipated to increase, accompanied by the continual mining of lithium, which might hinder its further application. Therefore, it is an urgent need to develop an alternative energy storage technology that could fill for LIBs [7,8]. Sodium (Na) is in the same alkaline group with lithium (Li) in the periodic table and shares similar chemistry/electrochemistry to Li. Contrary to Li, the resources for Na are abundant and widely distributed around the globe. Therefore, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are being considered as promising candidates to LIBs, particularly in the case of large-scale stationary energy storage field-type applications [1]. However, the larger ionic radius of Na+ (1.02 Å vs. 0.76 Å of Li+) and the higher standard electrochemical potential (−2.71 V Na/Na+ and −3.04 V Li/Li+ vs. SHE), result in the lower power and energy density for SIBs [9,10]. Moreover, graphite, the commercial anode material for LIBs, is not efficient for Na ion storage due to the larger ionic size of Na ions. An efficient anode material is a crucial factor that governs the future success of SIBs. The present researches on anode materials for SIBs could be categorized into three main groups according to their storage reactions: intercalation/de-intercalation reaction, conversion reaction, and the alloying/de-alloying reaction [11,12]. This includes carbonaceous materials, titanium-based materials, alloy materials, metal oxides/sulfides and organic materials [10,13]. Among them, carbonaceous materials have attracted more and more attention due to their low-cost, high structural stability and good electrical conductivity [14,15]. The hard carbons produced from various polymers and biomasses with a relatively high disordered degree and large interlayer distance, are considered to be favorable for Na ion insertion/extraction, and the Na-storage capacity usually can reach ~300 mAh g−1 with good cycle stability [16]. However, the highly disordered microstructure and the low degree of graphitization in hard carbon lead to diminished electrical conductivity, which results in the poor rate performance. In addition, the low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) due to the high surface area also adversely affect the energy density of the full cell configuration. Moreover, the low carbon yield and the relatively high cost also hinder the practical application of hard carbon anodes. Pitch is the composite of aromatic molecules with small size and low condensation degree, and is considered as a promising carbon precursor based on its high carbon content and abundant resources. Petroleum pitch and coal tar pitch (CTP) with different alkyl substitution and aromaticity are usually used as precursors to fabricate carbon materials [17–19]. These pitch types are abundant with oligomers of alkylated polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) which are composed of the aromatic nucleus (i.e., relatively stable conjugated sp 2 carbons) and side chains (i.e., peripheral sp 3 carbons), which can easily form the near parallel stacked carbon sheets during the heating process and are capable of being graphitized at high temperatures. As a result, pitch-based carbon materials usually demonstrate soft carbon nature with relatively high graphitization degree, few defects, and high electrical conductivity, recognizing it as a potential material in the energy storage field [20–22]. Pitch-based carbons have been intensively explored as electrode materials for supercapacitors and LIBs. Fabricating porous structure by template carbonization and alkali activation, as well as introducing heteroatoms have been identified as effective strategies to increase active sites and improve the electrochemical performance of pitch-based carbon electrodes [19–22]. Similarly, the research of finding suitable pitch-based carbon anodes for SIBs has attracted more and more attentions. Tracing back to 1993, the insertion reaction of sodium into carbons was first discussed by Doeff and co-workers [23]. The sodium storage performance of carbon materials prepared from different precursors was explored by galvanostatically charging/discharging at a current density of 50 μA cm−2 in ether-based electrolytes. The approximate compositions included NaC24 for Conoco petroleum coke (soft carbon), NaC15 for Shawinigan black, and NaC70 for the microcrystalline graphite, exhibiting the insufficient sodium storage performances of soft carbons. Thomas et al. investigated the Na-storage performance of the mesophase pitch-based carbon fibers P75 and P100 and revealed the formation mechanism and the composition of the formed surface passivated layer. It was found that the P75 carbon fibers could achieve a reversible capacity of Na0.31C8 (83 mAh g−1) [24,25], which was low and insufficient for practical application. The theoretical calculation indicates that a minimal interlayer spacing of 0.37 nm is needed for Na+ to overcome the energy barrier and intercalate into the carbon layers [26]. The mismatch between the small interlayer spacing of the pitch-derived carbon and the large radius of Na+ results in the insufficient Na-storage capacity of such carbons [27,28]. It is, however, believed that the low-cost pitch still has the great potential and is attractive to produce carbon anodes for the practical application of SIBs. How to adjust the microstructures and fabricate carbon materials with high Na+ storage capacity are the main bottle-neck issues restricting the development of the pitch-based carbon anode for SIBs. Many studies have explored the possibilities to improve the electrochemical Na-storage performances of the pitch-derived carbon materials, which include morphological adjustment and structural modification, as shown in Fig. 1 . Herein, we systematically review these studies and discuss the corresponding improvment mechanisms. Also, the future developments trends of the pitch-based carbon anodes for SIBs are prospected in this review. 2 Morphological adjustments In 2001, Stevens and Dahn [29] studied the Na-storage behavior and performances of different carbon materials, among them, soft carbons were prepared by pyrolyzing Crowley pitch at 1000 °C. The wide/small angle in situ X-ray scattering testing (WAXS/SAXS) were used to demonstrate the insertion of sodium into carbon materials. The study observed only a sloping region in the charge/discharge curve of pitch-derived carbon, which is typical Na-storage behavior of soft carbon. According to the in situ WAXS analysis, an increase of (002) interlayer spacing was observed when the cell was discharged along the sloping curve, which was attributed to the insertion of Na+ between the turbostratically disordered carbon layers. Some other attempts were also made to explore the performance of the carbons derived from direct pyrolysis of pitch and its derivatives, and they also exhibit the typical Na-storage behavior of soft-carbons, while the performances are poor and insufficient for application [30–34]. Despite the insufficient Na-storage capacity of directly pyrolyzed pitch-based carbons, these experiments demonstrate the possibility of pitch-based carbon materials for Na-storage, attracting scientific attention for the development of low-cost pitch-based carbon anode for SIBs. Recently, some strategies like constructing porous carbon, carbon fibers and carbon nanosheets, which could introduce more active Na-storage sites and defects, thus increasing Na-storage capacity have also been investigated to prepare pitch-derived carbon anodes for SIBs. 2.1 Porous structure The electrochemical performance of carbon materials is believed to be closely related to their microstructures. Designing a porous structure is an effective way to improve the electrochemical Na-storage performance for carbon anodes [35]. The common methods to fabricate the porous structure of carbon materials include template carbonization [36–38], inherent precursor structure formation [39–41], physical/chemical activation [19,21] and so on. Typically, the pores introduced by physical/chemical activation are mainly micropores (<2 nm), which can provide large surface area and ample adsorption sites for Na ion storage, thus enhancing surface capacitance contribution. Through template carbonization strategy, mesopores (2–50 nm) and macropores (>50 nm) can be constructed, which can facilitate the accessibility to electrolyte and provide channels for rapid ion transport/diffusion, leading to the improvement of rate capability [38,42,43]. Early in 2011, Wenzel et al. [44] prepared a porous carbon using the nano-casting process, with a mesophase pitch as a carbon precursor and hierarchical porous silica as a template. The obtained carbon material exhibited interconnected porous structures with a high surface area of 346 m2 g−1. This material, when tested as anodes for SIBs, delivered a reversible capacity of around 130 mAh g−1 at the rate of 0.2 C, corresponding to the nominal composition of NaC17. The developed hierarchical porosity allowed the carbon to demonstrate improved rate performance, and the reversible capacity still exceeded 100 mAh g−1 even at the higher rates of 2 C and 5 C. However, the removal of silica template involved the use of HF solution, which hinders the further development and practical application of this strategy. In contrast, Cao et al. [45] used nano-CaCO3 as a hard template, mesophase pitch as a carbon precursor to produce porous carbon (Fig. 2 a). In comparison to the silica template method, the nano-CaCO3 template is much cheaper and can be easily removed by using a dilute HCl solution. The nano-CaCO3 template could not only prevent the pitch from forming the highly ordered carbon structure, but also create a porous structure, which would improve the Na-storage property. The prepared porous carbon possessed a higher specific surface area of 113.1 m2 g−1 than 3.5 m2 g−1 for MPC (mesophase pitch-based carbon without the addition of nano-CaCO3 template). When used as an anode for SIBs, the porous carbon delivered an initial reversible capacity of 331 mAh g−1 at the current density of 30 mA g−1 (Fig. 2b), much higher than that of MPC (243 mAh g−1). Also, the reversible capacity of 103 mAh g−1 at 500 mA g−1 was maintained after 3000 cycles, demonstrating the superiority of porous structures in improving the rate performance. Unfortunately, the high surface area leads to more electrolyte consumption to form solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), resulting in the low ICE of 45%. Furthermore, using NaCl as the template, the 3D amorphous carbon (3DAC) was prepared from the mixture of low-cost pitch and phenolic resin (1/1 wt) [46,47], as illustrated in Fig. 2(c). Contrary to the traditional soft carbons, the obtained 3DAC contained order–disorder local structures, which are beneficial in structural modification of the pitch-based carbons. Compared to non-templated carbon (AC), the 3DAC showed well developed hierarchical porous structure with a surface area of 32.8 m2 g−1, and a pore volume of 0.074 cm3 g−1 (Fig. 2d, e). Accordingly, the 3DAC delivered a high reversible Na-storage capacity of 280.1 mAh g−1 at the current density of 30 mA g−1 and an ICE of 75%. Introducing porosity into the pitch-derived carbon structure can provide more active sites for Na+ storage [16], reduce the ion diffusion distances, and accommodate local volume expansion during the charge/discharge process [48], resulting in the improved reversible capacity, cycle stability and rate capability of the devised anode. However, the increased surface area and defects result in more electrolyte decomposition and formation of SEI during the charge/discharge process, leading to a lowering of ICE [49]. In addition, more Na+ will be trapped at the defect sites and create the repulsive electric field simultaneously [50], which is not beneficial for Na+ storage. Therefore, tuning the porous structure of carbon anode materials to achieve an optimum balance of high Na-storage capacity, high ICE, good cycle and rate performance is still a challenging task in the field of pitch-derived porous carbon. 2.2 Carbon nanofibers Fibrous carbon materials, with the predominated advantage of high mechanical strength, good electrical conductivity, and electrochemical properties, hold great promise in the development of advanced electrochemical energy storage devices [51]. Early in 2000, Thomas et al. [24,25] explored the performance of mesophase pitch-based carbon fibers P75 and P100 as anodes for SIBs. The carbon fibers with the diameter on micron scale and interlayer spacing of ~0.34 nm exhibited inferior Na-storage performance. The maximum reversible capacity of the pitch-based carbon fibers could only reach 83 mAh g−1 (Na0.31C8). Therefore, proper structure regulation is essential to improve the Na-storage performance of the pitch-based carbon fibers. The electrospinning method is a widely used advanced technique for fiber-formation. The fabricated carbon-based fibers can be directly used as a flexible and free-standing anode for SIBs, eliminating the use of inactive ingredients such as binders and current collectors. Utilizing the cheap asphalt (pitch) and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as precursors, and pluronic F127 as a soft template, Qi et al. [52] synthesized porous carbon nanofiber (PCF) with the diameter of ~100 nm by electrospinning method. Similarly, Wang and co-workers [53] prepared nitrogen-doped, free-standing, flexible carbon nanofiber films (NCFs), using coal tar pitch/polyacrylonitrile (PAN) mixture (1/1 wt) as a precursor, accompanied with NH3 treatment, as illustrated in Fig. 3 (a). The NH3 treatment etches the nanofibers also introduces surface pores and defects (Fig. 3b). The obtained NCFs have a diameter of 400 nm, with a nitrogen content of 5.7 at%, and a high surface area of 531 m2 g−1. There were both disordered and ordered regions in the carbon framework, which were expected to improve the Na-storage performance. Being directly used as flexible free-standing anodes for SIBs, the NCFs exhibited a high reversible capacity of 345 mAh g−1 at the current density of 0.1 A g−1, with a low ICE of 53.4%. NCFs demonstrated excellent rate performance and could deliver the reversible capacity of 156 mAh g−1 at the current density of 5 A g−1. Besides, reversible capacity was maintained at 235 mAh g−1 for 1 A g−1 and 217 mAh g−1 for 2 A g−1 after 10,000 cycles, showing the excellent cycle stability and rate performance of the derived NCFs (Fig. 3c). The carbon materials with fibrous structure have good electric conductivity, practical mechanical stability, and excellent stress tolerance [54–56], which could accommodate the local volume change and maintain the structural network during the charge/discharge process. Meanwhile, the fibrous structure could considerably shorten the Na+ diffusion distance, which facilitates the charge transfer process, and improves the electrode and electrolyte contact while enhancing the surface capacitive contribution of the carbon material [54,57], as shown in Fig. 3(d). The use of polyacrylonitrile (PAN), enables pitch materials to be transformed into carbon nanofibers, through electrospinning technology under high temperature carbonization. The produced free-standing carbon nanofibers can be directly used as anode materials for SIBs, and the Na-storage performance of the pitch-derived carbon nanofibers is appealing, including the improved cycle stability and rate performance. However, the complicated and time-consuming fabrication process coupled with low yield makes it an unsuitable approach to producing low cost for pitch-derived carbons. In addition, the much-exposed surface area of the porous fiber structures leads to more irreversible reactions, resulting in the declined ICE. These problems need attention before fibrous pitch-based carbon anodes could be advanced for the commercial market. 2.3 Carbon nanosheets Pitch is abundant with alkylated polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), which are similar to the hexagonally ranged carbon atoms in graphene. The aromatic hydrocarbons could be polymerized and further aromatized into large interconnected thin polymeric films, thereby transforming into carbon nanosheets at high temperatures [58]. The carbon materials with nanosheets structure usually have excellent mechanical flexibility and high electrochemical conductivity thus exhibit tremendous potential in the energy storage field. Compared with other reagents, inorganic salts such as KCl and NaCl can be easily removed using deionized water and could be recycled after the drying process. It is reported that glucose could be converted into carbon nanosheets by tuning the carbonization conditions in the liquid molten-salt medium [59]. Inspired by this, Wang et al. [60] prepared graphene-like carbon nanosheets utilizing the low-cost petroleum-asphalt as the carbon precursor with eutectic composition of NaCl/KCl (4.5:5.5 by weight, with a melting point of 657 °C) as a template, as illustrated in Fig. 4 (a). During the heating process, the eutectic salts started to melt and gradually form a liquid media when the temperature reached 657 °C. The high temperature led to the pyrolysis of petroleum-asphalt into carbon, which was pushed out under the cooling process, via crystallization of salts. After removing the crystallized salts, the carbon nanosheets (MSC) with the thickness of below 20 nm were easily obtained (Fig. 4b). Compared with the carbon (PAC) prepared by direct pyrolysis of petroleum-asphalt without the addition of eutectic salts, the MSC shows significantly improved electrochemical Na-storage performance. The initial reversible Na-storage capacity of MSC can reach 279 mAh g−1 at the current density of 50 mA g−1, superior to PAC (~175 mAh g−1). In addition, the rate capability of MSC enhanced at various current densities compared to PAC (Fig. 4c, d). However, due to the more exposed surface and the increased irreversible reactions for SEI formation, the ICE of the MSC could only reach ~41%. Apart from the eutectic of inorganic salts, other strategies could also be used to fabricate the nanosheets structure. According to the templating and confining effect of the salts, Hao et al. [61] prepared N-doped porous carbon nanosheets from the coal tar pitch by using NaCl as a template under NH3 treatment. The surface area of the derived carbon with wrinkled sheets morphology could reach 546 m2 g−1. As a result, the prepared carbon exhibited excellent Na-storage performance with a high capacity of 144 mAh g−1 at the current density of 2 A g−1 over 10,000 charge/discharge cycles. Melamine is an N-containing precursor with low cost, which could be converted into the graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) with nanosheet structure at 600 °C, and completely decomposed at 900 °C. This characteristic enables melamine to act as a potential candidate for in situ self-sacrificial templates to fabricate two-dimensional (2D) sheet-like morphology [62]. Using melamine as the sacrificial template, Gao and co-workers [63] synthesized N, P co-doped 2D carbon sheet by carbonizing the mixture of petroleum pitch, melamine and supermolecular (assembled by melamine and phytic acid). When used as the anode for SIBs, the N, P co-doped carbon nanosheets could deliver a high capacity of 285 mAh g−1 at the current density of 200 mA g−1 with an ICE of 42%, besides excellent cycle and rate performance. Carbon nanosheets could not only provide continuous conducting pathways for the electron transfer, enhancing the ion-transport capability across the nanosheets, but also afford enough space to buffer the volume expansion during the sodiation/desodiation process. In addition, the highly exposed surface area can offer a large number of active Na+ storage sites on both sides of the nanosheets [64–66], which can enhance the capacitive capacity as well as the reversible capacity of the final electrode. Nevertheless, the fabrication processes of pitch-based carbon with sheet-like morphology is usually complicated, requiring precise control of the sheets morphology. Moreover, a larger amount of electrolyte would be consumed in forming SEI on the exposed surface of nanosheets, resulting in a lower ICE value, which further hinders the practical application of pitch-based carbon with nanosheet like structure as the anode materials. 3 Heteroatoms doping Heteroatom doping (such as N, P, S, B, F) is recognized as an efficient method to improve the electrochemical performances of carbon materials, which can increase the active sites by introducing defects and enhance the conductivity [67]. Hence, this strategy has been widely applied to modify carbon materials for energy storage, including improving the Na-storage performances of pitch-derived carbons. Nitrogen (N) is the commonly used doping element for carbon materials and has been extensively studied. The doped N atoms have high electronegativity, and could be classified into three forms in the carbon framework: pyridinic N (N-6), pyrrolic N (N-5) and graphitic N (N-Q), corresponding to the approximate location in 398.5 ± 0.5 eV, 400.0 ± 0.5 eV, 401.0 ± 0.5 eV on the N 1 s spectrum, respectively [68–71], as shown in Fig. 5 (a, b). Theoretically, the pyridinic N (N-6) and pyrrolic N (N-5) are located at the defect sites or edges of the carbon framework. In contrast, graphitic N (N-Q) refers to substitute for C atoms in the hexagonal rings. According to the density functional theory (DFT) calculation (Fig. 5c), the coordinating energy (E coord) of N-5 (−6.45 eV) and N-6 (−9.26 eV) are higher than N-Q (−4.33 eV), indicating that the edge-nitrogen (N-5 and N-6) are energetically more favorable for Na+ storage [72,73]. As a result, the electrical conductivity would be improved by N-doping, where the generated defects could provide active sites for Na+ storage, and facilitate diffusion/transportation, enhancing the pseudo-capacitance Na-storage capacity [72,74]. Using coal tar pitch as the precursor and NaCl as a template, Hao and co-workers [61] prepared porous carbon nanosheets (PCNS1000) with N doping by two-step carbonization at 700 °C in Ar and NH3/Ar atmosphere at 1000 °C. The NH3 etching results in disordered carbon with reduced nanocrystalline clusters, along with N atoms introduced into carbon framework. As a result, the pitch-derived carbon with a N content of 4.17 wt% and an interlayer distance of 0.382 nm was obtained, which could deliver a reversible Na-storage capacity of 296 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 with an ICE of 66%. The improved electrical conductivity of PCNS1000 enabled excellent rate performance, with a maintained capacity of 124 mAh g−1 at the current density of 10 A g−1, relatively superior to that of the carbon prepared without NH3 treatment (CNS1000) (63 mAh g−1), as shown in Fig. 5(d). Moreover, PCNS1000 also demonstrated extraordinary structural stability and cycle performance, with a stable reversible capacity of 123.8 mAh g−1 at the current density of 2 A g−1 after ultra-long 10,000 cycles (Fig. 5e). Phosphorus (P) atom has a larger covalent radius of 111 pm compared to C (75 pm), S (103 pm), N (71 pm), and O (63 pm). Thus, the interlayer spacing of carbon materials could be significantly enlarged by P-doping, which could be beneficial for Na-ion transportation [64,75]. In addition, the theoretical simulations (Fig. 6 a, b) demonstrate that doping with P can enhance the adsorption of Na+, improve the electronic conductivity, decrease the diffusion barrier, and facilitate the charge transfer for Na+ uptake [76,77]. Taking the coal tar pitch (CTP) as a carbon precursor, mixed with H3PO4, Miao et al. [78] prepared a P-doped soft carbon (PSC) with a P-doping content of 3.42 at%. The PSC, when used as anodes for SIBs, exhibited the typical Na-storage behavior of soft carbon where only slope region was observed in the charge/discharge curve (Fig. 6c). PSC demonstrated the high reversible capacity of 251 mAh g−1 at the current density of 100 mA g−1 (158 mAh g−1 for CSC, without P doping) with excellent cycle and rate capability, as shown in Fig. 6(d, e). In comparison to single-atom doping, co– and multi-atoms doping could combine the properties of the different doped atoms, thus synergizing the coupling effect, and leading to improved electrochemical performances [79]. Carbon materials with co– or multi-heteroatoms doping have attracted significant attention in SIBs. For example, N, P dual-doping can introduce large number of defects and expand the layer planes, thus increasing the active sites for Na-ion storage, and facilitating the fast ion diffusion/transport. The substitutional atoms would be incorporated into the structure at the edge-plane sites, leading to the increased electrical conductivity and improved wettability [80]. From the recent research, a new concept of building the electron-rich regions on the electrode surface was proposed [81]. The formed electron-rich regions by doping with N, P atoms could afford strong attraction to the cations and accelerate the charge transfer, as a result, the derived carbon material could increase the capacitance without sacrificing the density, conductivity, and stability of the whole electrode. A melamine-phytic acid supermolecular aggregate (MPSA) containing N and P atoms could be formed via the cooperative assembly of melamine and phytic acid in water at room temperature, which could be used as the N, P-doping agent [82]. Gao et al. [63] prepared the N, P co-doped carbon nanosheets (NP-CNSs) by carbonizing the mixture of petroleum pitch with melamine and supermolecular polymer (assembled by phytic acid and melamine) (Fig. 7 a). Taking advantage of N (11.2 at%) and P (5.8 at%) co-doping, electron-rich regions were formed, with the interlayer spacing increasing from 0.34 nm to 0.41 nm. According to the theoretical calculation (Fig. 7b), the change of charges on carbon atoms around N-6 and phosphate group (~C2PO3) was significant, demonstrating its potential for cation attraction. This material, when used as anodes for SIBs, delivered the highest reversible Na+ storage capacity of 285 mAh g−1 at 200 mA g−1. In addition, the NP-CNSs exhibited extraordinary rate performance, and could maintain a reversible capacity of 140 mAh g−1 at the current density of 5 A g−1 (Fig. 7c, d). Moreover, the NP-CNSs showed excellent cycle stability and stabilized capacity of 187 mAh g−1 over 4,000 cycles at the current density of 1 A g−1 (Fig. 7e). The report suggested the prospects of N/P co-doped pitch-derived carbon materials in Na-storage devices with new-path ways to further improve the electrochemical performances. Heteroatoms doping especially the co– or multi- doping strategy, holds the great potential in improving the performance of the pitch-derived carbon materials. Here, the doping type and doping level are the key parameters that can affect the microstructure, electronic distribution, active sites, diffusion resistance, and energy barriers. Therefore, heteroatoms doping with suitable atom species and appropriate doping levels are essential factors that govern the future development of the pitch-based carbon materials. 4 Heterostructure fabrication Hard carbons and soft carbons with intrinsic structural differences exhibit specific Na-storage behaviors and mechanisms. The structure of hard carbons is highly disordered with larger interlayer spacing, which is essential in improving the ionic conductivity while facilitating the Na+ insertion/extraction between the carbon layers resulting in a relatively high reversible Na-storage capacity of ~ 300 mAh g−1. Besides, the typical charge/discharge curve of hard carbon consists of low-potential plateau region and high-potential sloping region, corresponding to the different Na-storage mechanisms [83–85]. However, due to the highly disordered carbon structure and decreased electronic conductivity, hard carbon anodes suffers low ICE value and insufficient rate performance, meanwhile, the high precursors' cost and low carbon yield are also the impediments to their superiority [86,87]. In contrast, pitch-derived soft carbons with low-cost usually have excellent electronic conductivity with the relatively higher graphitization degree, fewer defects, and the more well-developed carbon frameworks. However, the smaller interlayer spacing in pitch-derived soft carbons is insufficient for the insertion/extraction of Na+ between the carbon layers, resulting in that only a sloping region displayed in the charge/discharge curve and the low reversible Na+ storage capacity [88–90]. Therefore, a strategy that combines the high capacity of hard-carbons with the good rate performance of soft-carbons could be a viable route to obtain the carbon materials with promising Na-storage performances. As described above, there is a unique concept of fabricating carbon heterostructure [91–93], by a combination of highly disordered hard carbon structure with the relatively ordered soft carbon structure to realize controllable amorphous hard-soft heterostructure. Here hard carbon components could increase the Na-storage sites and enhance the storage capacity, while the soft carbon component could promote the electronic conductivity and improve the structural stability. The synergistic effect between the hard and soft components could develop a reformed microcrystalline and achieve comprehensive improvements, including the reversible capacity, cycle stability, and rate performance of carbon anode materials. Li et al. [92] introduced phenolic resin into the pitch to adjust the microcrystalline of pitch-derived carbon and obtained a series of pitch/phenolic resin-derived amorphous carbons (PPAC) by changing the mass ratio of pitch to phenolic resin and the carbonization temperature. The (002) peak in X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Fig. 8 a) was broadened and downshifted with the increase of phenolic resin, indicating the increased disordered degree and enlarged interlayer spacing of PPAC. This confirmed that phenolic resin could successfully suppress the microcrystalline growth of pitch-derived carbon particles. Also, the high carbon yield and low cost of pitch can significantly decrease the cost of the PPACs. As shown in Fig. 8(b), the electrochemical Na-storage curves of all the PPACs consist of the plateau region below 0.1 V and the sloping region above 0.1 V. The reversible capacity of PPAC371400 (pitch/phenolic resin with the weight ratio of 3/7, carbonized under the temperature of 1400 °C) could reach 284 mAh g−1 with a high ICE of 88% at 0.1 C (30 mA g−1). In contrast, the pitch-derived carbon (carbonized at 1400 °C) delivered a low capacity of only 85 mAh g−1 at 30 mA g−1 with a sloping storage region observed in the charge/discharge curve (Fig. 8c). The rate capability is influenced by the electronic conductivity and the ionic conductivity of the electrode, thus excessive content of phenolic resin or pitch content having a negative effect. Herein, PPAC111400 exhibited the best rate performance of 165 mAh g−1 at 1 C (300 mA g−1) and 90 mAh g−1 at 2 C (600 mA g−1), which was attributed to the balance between the electronic conductivity and ionic conductivity. Subsequently, the low cost lignin was also employed to adjust the structure of pitch-derived amorphous carbon (AC) [93]. Lignin is a kind of water-soluble hard carbon precursor, and is identified to be able to emulsify pitch, which means the cross linked structure would be generated between pitch and lignin, as shown in Fig. 8(d). The movements of C − H stretching peak of methyl and methylene groups and bending vibration peak of the benzene ring of lignin, as well as the aromatic skeletal vibration peak of pitch in fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) indicate the existence of interaction between the hydrogen atom of lignin and some atomic groups of pitch, leading to the increase of stretching or bending vibration energy. As a result, the amorphous carbon with an enhanced disordered degree was obtained, and the interlayer distance increased from 0.345 nm for the pitch-derived soft carbon to 0.361 nm for the AC amorphous carbon, with La values reduced from 5.53 nm to 4 nm. The obtained AC amorphous carbon demonstrated an improved electrochemical Na-storage capacity of 254 mAh g−1 at 30 mA g−1 with an enhance ICE of 82% (Fig. 8e), while the reversible capacity of pitch-derived carbon was only 85 mAh g−1 with an ICE of 58%. Fabricating a hard-soft heterostructure is an efficient strategy to adjust the structure of pitch-derived carbons, which could suppress the graphitization, enlarge the interlayer spacing, and facilitate the kinetic of Na+ insertion/extraction reactions. Moreover, the electrochemical Na-storage behavior in the low-potential plateau region could be observed in the charge/discharge curves, which is essential in improving the energy density of the full cells while coupling with cathodes. It should be noted that the ratios of soft/hard and the carbonization conditions are the key parameters to obtain high performance and low cost pitch-derived carbon materials with the heterostructure for SIBs, which deserves further research and exploration. 5 Disordered crystalline structure formation The direct pyrolysis of pitch at high temperature results in soft carbons with relatively high graphitization degree and smaller interlayer spacing, unsuitable for Na+ insertion/extraction. While it is believed that the oxidation treatment can effectively stabilize the structure of pitch molecules and prevent its softening and melting during the carbonization process by forming the cross-linking network between the molecules [94–96], resulting in more disordered crystalline structures with enlarged interlayer spacing, which exhibit the typical Na-storage behavior of hard carbon. Inspired by the oxidative stabilization process, Yuan et al. [97] used the MCMBs derived from coal tar pitch as carbon precursor, followed by air-oxidation and high temperature carbonization to prepare the carbon material (OC-MCMB). The MCMBs were built from basic spherical units, rich in aromatic molecular layers with large molecular weight. After being oxidized in air, a large number of oxygen atoms would be introduced, resulting in cross-linkage between carbon layers. Further carbonization at high temperature under the inert atmosphere, the OC-MCMB was obtained with more defect sites, larger interlayer spacing, and lower graphitization degree. According to the FTIR analysis, the introduced oxygen atoms are mainly in the form of carbonyl groups (C = O), which can increase cross-linkage between the aromatic molecules and enlarge the interlayer spacing of the carbon materials. When used as an anode for SIBs, the OC-MCMB could deliver an initial reversible capacity of 286 mAh g−1 at the current density of 25 mA g−1 and maintain 79 mAh g−1 when the current density increased to 3.2 A g−1. Recently, by pyrolyzing pristine pitch under a low temperature of 800 °C, Qi and co-workers [98] prepared carbons with highly disordered crystalline structures and abundant oxygen atoms (mainly in C=O and C−O forms) compared to that of high temperature carbonization. The high disordered degree and defect concentration provide more active sites for Na-storage, resulting in a higher Na-storage capacity of 263 mAh g−1 and ICE of 80% at the current density of 40 mA g−1, much higher than 74 mAh g−1 for the carbon obtained at 1550 °C. Also, Lu et al. [90] employed the two-step strategy of pre-oxidization in the air, followed by carbonization at 1400 °C in Ar to synthesize pitch-based carbon material (CPOP). According to the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) test, there is a 6% weight increase between 200 and 290 °C, which was attributed to the oxygen acquisition. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), the introduced oxygen atoms were recognized in the form of carbonyl (C=O, e.g., ester and anhydride), where these oxygen functional groups could generate the cross-linking reactions, resulting in the more disordered structure and increased carbon yield (from 54% to 67%) after the high-temperature carbonization process. As shown in Fig. 9(b), contrary to the Na-storage behavior of pitch-derived carbon from direct pyrolysis (CPP), which only exhibits a monotone high-potential sloping region in the charge/discharge curves, the charge/discharge curve of CPOPs consists of the low-potential plateau region and high-potential sloping region, typical of hard carbons Na-storage behavior, indicating that an effective structural conversion from ordered to disordered is realized by pre-oxidation treatment in air. Pre-oxidation time and temperature, as well as the carbonization temperature, could influence the O content, cross-linking level, and the graphitization degree of CPOPs. The CPOP-300 °C –3h-1400 °C could deliver a high initial reversible capacity of 301 mAh g−1 at the current density of 30 mA g−1 with an ICE of 88.6%. The significantly improved Na-storage capacity (301 mAh g−1 vs. 94.0 mAh g−1 for CPP-1400 °C without pre-oxidation treatment) verifies the superiority of the microstructure of CPOP prepared by the pre-oxidation strategy. The possible reaction mechanism of pre-oxidation treatment to prepare the disordered carbon is demonstrated in Fig. 9(c). Using the mixture of pitch and phenol–formaldehyde resin (PR) (weight ratio of 1:1) as carbon precursor, Sun and co-workers [99] synthesized amorphous carbon (AC), by low-temperature pre-oxidation at 220 °C and followed carbonization at 1000 °C. After the air-oxidation, the introduced oxygen and oxygen functional groups could further promote the cross-linked polymerization, leading to the more disordered carbon structure with the I D/I G ratio increased from 1.56 to 2.20, the carbon yield enhanced from ~ 55% to ~ 70% and the interlayer spacing increased from 0.353 nm to 0.376 nm. In comparison to the directly pyrolyzed carbon, which showed a low Na-storage capacity of only 130 mAh g−1, the amorphous carbons derived with pre-oxidation treatment exhibited improved electrochemical Na-storage performance, where the initial reversible capacity can reach 268.3 mAh g−1 at 30 mA g−1 with the ICE of 82%. The positive ion type polymerization reaction could also be performed to modify the raw pitch materials [100]. Using the 1,4-benzenedimethanol (PXG) as a modifier, and p-toluene sulfonic acid (PTS) as a catalyst, Wang et al. has successfully modified the pitch with increased softening point from 75 °C to 112 °C. The content of aliphatic hydrogen increased simultaneously, confirming the generated cross-linking reactions and the suppressed π-π interactions by introducing the PXG, as illustrated in Fig. 10 (a). The modified pitch was further mixed with NaCl template and subsequently carbonized at 750 °C, to produce pitch-derived carbon frameworks (MCF750) with disordered three-dimensional porous structure. In addition, the heteroatoms were also introduced by the addition of a cross-linking agent into the MCF750 with the nitrogen content of 2.8 at% and oxygen of 5.49 at%, which were beneficial for Na-storage. According to the DFT calculations (Fig. 10b), the interactions between Na+ and C = O shows the more considerable Gibbs free energy change (ΔG), verifying that the active oxygen-containing groups could enhance the Na-storage performance for pitch-derived carbon. As a result, the MCF750 delivered a high initial reversible capacity of 272 mAh g−1 at the current density of 0.1 A g−1 (Fig. 10c). The capacity was maintained at 121 mAh g−1 when the current density increased to 10 A g−1, demonstrating an improved Na-storage performance by the PXG modification strategy for the pitch-derived carbon. An amphiphilic carbon material (ACM) with vast polyaromatic hydrocarbon rigid segments was prepared from coal tar pitch by nitro-sulfuric acid treatment [101,102]. Liu and co-workers [103] used the ACM as a precursor, with an easy oxidizing acid treatment and 1000 °C catalytic graphitization to prepare the heteroatom-doped hard/soft hybrids. Herein, the Fe(NO3)3∙9H2O was used as a catalyst, followed by the HNO3 oxidation. Finally, N and O heteroatoms were introduced into the obtained carbon and forming a hard/soft hybrids structures with abundant defects. As a result, the Na-storage capacity was greatly increased from 113 mAh g−1 to 306 mAh g−1 at 25 mA g−1. Very recently, Qi et al. [104] proposed an in-situ Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O solidification (ISMS) strategy to convert the fusion-state to solid-state carbonization of the pitch-based carbon, as illustrated in Fig. 11 (a). It is known that precursors with excessive hydrogen would form the viscous carbonaceous residues, leading to the compact and high-density graphitized carbons. During the gradual decomposition of Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O, some oxygen species (such as O2, NO2, and NO) would be released, which could consume the excessive hydrogen of the pitch, and prevent the formation of viscous carbonaceous residues. Due to the chemical interactions and the suppressed graphitization, the carbon yield increased from 61% to 92%. The derived carbon materials exhibited a highly disordered structure with more defect sites (Fig. 11b), and the interlayer spacing was enlarged from 0.34 nm ~ 0.36 nm to 0.37 nm ~ 0.40 nm. When used as an anode for SIBs, the PC1400-ISMS (pitch-based carbon derived in 1400 °C by the ISMS strategy) delivered the typical Na-storage behavior of hard carbon, with the charge/discharge curve consisting of the low-potential plateau region and high-potential sloping region (Fig. 11c). The reversible capacity of PC1400-ISMS could reach 278 mAh g−1 at the current density of 30 mA g−1 with an ICE of 80.19%, which was higher than that of PC1400 obtained using conventional carbonization strategy without the addition of Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O (Fig. 11d). This reflected the improved sodium storage capacity of the pitch-derived carbon materials by using ISMS strategy. In summary, the cross-linking network could be formed by the pre-treatment in air or by introducing the extra reagents, which could suppress the melting and graphitization of pitch materials during pyrolysis. As a result, the produced pitch-based carbons realize an increased degree of disordered and enlarged interlayer spacing. Moreover, the appearance of the low-potential plateau region in the charge/discharge curve is appealing to understand the relationship between the structure and the Na-storage behavior of carbon materials with prospects for pitch-based carbon anodes in SIBs. As mentioned above, pitch-derived carbon materials have been widely studied as anodes for SIBs, and the present strategies along with the electrochemical Na-storage performances of the reported pitch-based carbon anodes are summarized in Table 1 . 6 Conclusions and prospects Pitch is an excellent precursor of carbon materials with low cost and high carbon content, that could meet the demands of SIBs on the commercial scale. However, the high graphitization degree and small interlayer distance of the pitch-derived carbon materials are not suitable for the Na-storage application. The current strategies focus on the morphology and structural adjustment of the pitch-derived carbon to increase the active sites and facilitate the ion diffusion/transportation, leading to improvement in the electrochemical Na-storage performances. The proper morphology adjustment, such as fabricating porous structures, nanofibrous and nanosheet-like morphology, could enhance the active sites, increase the capacitive contribution, and shorten the diffusion distance of electron and ion. However, the bottle-neck issue, in that case, includes the highly exposed area and increased defect sites, which lead to more irreversible reactions and reduced ICE value. In addition, the sloping region Na-storage behavior is adverse to the energy density of the device, and the low tap density of the porous carbon is usually not appealing for the industrial application. Moreover, the complex and tedious preparing processes, as well as the low yield, impair the advantage of pitch-derived carbons for practical application. Therefore, much more efforts should be focused on the development of facile preparation technology, as well as the appropriate morphology regulation to balance the sodium storage active sites and surface area of pitch-derived carbons to generate high capacity without sacrificing the ICE value and density. Heteroatom doping can increase the active sites by introducing defects, and enhance the conductivity, which is beneficial for the improvement of Na-storage capacity and rate performance of pitch-derived carbon. However, the accurate control of the content and type of heteroatom in pitch-derived carbons is still a big challenge. The synthesis procedure usually involves heat treatment of pitch precursors with heteroatom-containing compounds, which would cause the loss of heteroatoms and thus the uncertainty of content and type of doped heteroatoms. The content of doped heteroatom in carbon is often very low, and the doping type (e.g., pyrrolic-N and pyridinic-N) is difficult to regulate. Therefore, new doping agents and novel doping routes should be further developed for practical application of the heteroatoms doped pitch-derived carbons. For the co– or multi-doping carbon, controlling the contents of the heteroatoms to maximize the synergic effect deserves more attention for future development. The structure modification by fabricating heterostructures and pre-oxidation treatment could effectively restrict the melting of the pitch while increasing the disordered degree and enlarging the interlayer spacing. This is beneficial for Na+ insertion/extraction and the diffusion kinetics of ions and electrons, resulting in the enhanced Na-storage capacity, and relatively high ICE (>80%). Impressively, by fabricating heterostructures and pre-oxidation treatment, the pitch-derived carbons show similar Na-storage behavior to hard carbon, and the low-potential plateau region appears in the charge/discharge curve. It’s meaningful to further explore the corresponding structure transformation mechanisms and the related Na-storage behaviors. The facile fabrication procedure, as well as the significantly improved Na-storage performance, including high plateau region capacity and high ICE, endows the present modification strategy with broad prospect for application. Pitch-derived carbon materials hold significant application advantages for low cost sodium storage. Nonetheless, the components and structure of pitch are incredibly complicated, and the difference in structure characteristics for various pitch can cause different Na-storage properties of pitch-derived carbon anodes. There may be significant differences in the surface morphology and structure for pyrolytic carbons from different categories of pitch, even if at the same carbonization condition. For future development, it is of great significance to fully understand the composition of various kinds of pitch and perform the modification strategy based on the individual structure properties. The Na-storage mechanism is complicated due to the structural diversity of carbon materials. A fundamental understanding of the charge storage mechanism and the correlation between the surface components/microstructure and the Na-storage property is essential for the rational design and structural engineering of pitch-derived carbon materials. To get more specific and direct information regarding the Na-storage process, advanced characterization techniques are needed, especially in situ analytical tools to monitor the structure variation of carbon anodes at different charge/discharge states. Besides, the structure evolution from highly ordered to amorphous state by fabricating heterostructures or pre-oxidation treatment, accompanied by the Na-storage behavior changing from soft carbon to hard carbon, seems to provide a creative idea to elucidate the relationship between the structure and Na-storage behaviors of pitch-derived carbon materials. As improving the energy density is a great challenge for SIBs, it is desirable to develop pitch-derived carbon anodes with high initial CE and high low-potential plateau region capacity. The ultimate goal is to promote and achieve the commercial application of pitch-derived carbon materials in SIBs. Therfore, more modification strategies with simple and environmental-friendly manufacture process should be developed for large-scale production of pitch-derived carbons. Along with the continuous achievements on the improvement of Na-storage performance, the low-cost pitch-derived carbons hold great promise as next-generation SIBs anode. Mingchi Jiang got his bachelor degree from Beijing University of Chemical Technology (BUCT) in 2018. Now he is pursuing a master’s degree at Beijing University of Chemical Technology supervised by Prof. Bin Xu. His research interests mainly focus on carbon anodes for secondary batteries. Ning Sun received her Ph.D. degree in 2019 from Beijing University of Chemical technology (BUCT). She is now working as a post doctorate researcher in BUCT. Her main research interests include synthesis of carbon materials and 2D MXene for application in energy storage, such as supercapacitors, and sodium-/potassium-ion batteries. Razium A. Soomro obtained his Ph.D. from the National Centre of Excellence in Analytical Chemistry (NCEAC) Sindh, Jamshoro in 2016. At present, he is working as a post doctorate researcher in Beijing University of Chemical Technology (BUCT). His area of expertise includes nanomaterials with application scope in sensors, energy, catalysis, and environment. Bin Xu received his Ph.D. degree in 2006 from Beijing Institute of Technology. He worked in Drexel University as a visiting professor in 2016–2017. His current research interests focus on carbon materials and MXene-based materials for energy storage, including supercapacitors, secondary batteries such as lithium-/sodium-/potassium-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur batteries, electrocatalyst and sensors. He has published more than 100 peer-reviewed papers in international journals with citations over 6000 times and H-index of 41.

coredata.dc:description: Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have attracted significant attentions as promising alternatives to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage applications. Here carbon materials are considered as the most competitive anodes for SIBs based on their low-cost, abundant availability and excellent structural stability. Pitch, with high carbon content and low cost, is an ideal raw precursor to prepare carbon materials for large-scale applications. Nevertheless, the microstructures of pitch-based carbon are highly ordered with smaller interlayer distances, which are unfavorable for Na ion storage. Many efforts have been made to improve the sodium storage performance of pitch-based carbon materials. This review summarizes the recent progress about the application of pitch-based carbons for SIBs anodes in the context of carbon's morphology and structure regulation strategies, including morphology adjustment, heteroatoms doping, fabricating heterostructures, and the increase of the degree of disorder. Besides, the advantages, present challenges, and possible solutions to current issues in pitch-based carbon anode are discussed, with the highlight of future research directions. This review will provide a deep insight into the development of low-cost and high-performance pitch-based carbon anode for SIBs.
